p: Proton ( 1H) nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy enables the detection of terminal protons of n‐3 methyl (n‐3 CH 3) and non‐n‐3 methyl (CH 3) groups in FA chains at two different frequencies (ν): 0.98 and 0.90 ppm. 6, 7, 8 The methyl protons are coupled to two protons on the second carbon atom and form triplets in the NMR spectra. In the case of the n‐3 CH 3 group, the J‐coupling constant is 7.5 Hz. 9 The relatively adjacent base frequencies and signal splitting make the detection of n‐3 FA in vivo challenging. The in vivo fraction of n‐3 FA from the total FA chain is very low, ~1:75 in adipose tissue. 9 This complicates its detection and prolongs signal acquisition times.
